title: Who are the Britain's Got Talent: The Champions finalists? Full line-up confirmed
text:
Get the biggest celebs stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

Over the last few weeks talented acts from around the world have battled it out to be crowned the first ever winner of Britain's Got Talent: The Champions.

Acrobatics, singers, magicians and knife throwers and a whole lot more have given it their all in the name of entertainment.

As usual, judges Simon Cowell, Amanda Holden, Alesha Dixon and David Walliams have cast a critical eye over proceedings and picked one Golden Buzzer act each - but it's been ultaimately up to the audiences to decide who makes the final ten.

The show has not been without its twists, with fan favourite Paul Potts being booted out in the first week.

Now the ten acts left standing will perform for a final time in the hope of taking home the coveted trophy.

Here's who will be competing in Saturday's final...

Kseniya Simonova - Amanda's Golden Buzzer Act

(Image: ITV)

The winner of Ukrain's Got Talent Series One moved the audience to tears with her stunning artwork.

Using just sand, a projector and her bare hands, Kseniya is able to tell touching stories that impressed all of the judges, particularly Amanda who pressed her Golden Buzzer.

Before her act, Kseniya told explained that she works with children battling cancer and creates sand stories to "encourage them to keep on fighting".

Alexa Lauenburger - Ant and Dec's Golden Buzzer Act

11-year-old Alexa won the German edition of BGT with her incredible dog act.

Her triumph wasn't without its controversy. It later emerged the youngster had not trained the dogs herself when her dad performed on German TV with a very similar performance.

Despite the drama, Alexa was back in action for BGT: The Champions - along with her eight pooches - to impress the judges and viewers with a series of tricks.

But it was Geordie duo Ant and Dec who were the most enthralled, using their Golden Buzzer vote to send Alexa straight to the final.

Ant said it was 'one of the best dog acts we've ever had on Britain's Got Talent."

Paddy & Nico - David's Golden Buzzer Act

(Image: ITV)

David Walliams became uncharacteristically emotional by the salsa dancing duo and sent them straight through to the final.

Age-defying Nico, 85, and dance partner Paddy, 45, had the whole audience on their feet as they performed a number of fast moves.

At one point Nico grabbed Paddy by her hand and foot and swung her around in the air, before sweeping her across the stage floor.

As the dance came to an end, those in the crowd immediately told David to press his buzzer, while the pair were clearly emotional.

David told them: "There are very few acts you can watch with a smile on your face, and tears in your eyes.

"This is one of the most joyous, most beautiful, most life affirming acts we've ever had on Britain's Got Talent."

In sweet scenes Paddy then told David: "David is a very special name to me, it was my husband's name," to which in a tribute he replied: "This is for him."

Stavros Flatley - Simon's Golden Buzzer Act

(Image: ITV)

What started as a hilarious outtake on Michael Flatley's Lord of the Dance routine, has ended up being a very lucrative turn for the father-son dance duo.

The favourites from Britain's Got Talent series Three impressed head judge Simon so much on their comeback that he awarded them a place in Saturday's final.

But despite their popularity, the pair stunned fans by announcing they are to split just days before the final.

23-year-old Lagi Demetriou said that he will leave the group so that he can concentrate on his barber shop in Cyprus.

With Satuday's performance now being their swansong, could the duo go all the way?

Twist and Pulse - Alesha's Golden Buzzer Act

(Image: ITV)

Alesha's pick narrowly missed out on the top prize on Britain's Got Talent Series 4, but after losing out to Spellbound this time they'll be hoping they can go all the way.

Twist & Pulse, otherwise known as Ashley Glaze and Glen Murphy, combine street dance with comic asides for a very unique performance.

When Alesha sent the London lads straight through to the final three the delighted duo cried: "This means so much to us!"

"I know it does, I loved every minute of it," Alesha replied.

Bello and Annaliese Nock

(Image: Dymond/Thames/Syco/REX)

The father and dance duo describe themselves as 'Comic Daredevils' and the fearless family members are bound to put on an epic show on Saturday's final.

In their heat, Bello and Annaliese performed one of the most dangerous acts in the show's history.

There were serious fears that father and daughter duo Bello and Annaliese Nock would die during their death-defying routine in 'the wheel of death'.

The daredevil Americans could easily have fallen to their deaths while rotating in giant rings on separate ends of a swing that kept getting faster.

The judges had their hearts in their mouths as they watched the pair jumping, doing flips and climbing on the contraption.

Bello then pretended he was losing his balance and seemed like he was going to fall.

Amanda Holden's jaw dropped, David Walliams struggled to watch, and Ant confessed: "That was one of the scariest things I’ve ever seen."

What will they have up their sleeves for the final?

Mersey Girls

(Image: Tom Dymond)

Julie, Annie, Alice, Rebecca and Poppy formed Mersey Girls when they were just five years old. BGT viewers will remember the talented troupe from Series 11 in 2017.

Now they're set to take to the stage once again in The Champions finals.

Alesha even admitted that had she not already used her golden buzzer, the girls would most certainly receive it.

Simon has a special relationship with the group. He was so moved by the story of Julie Carlie, who was born with painful back condition scoliosis that he used his own money to pay for her to have life-changing surgery so she could continue dancing.

Speaking to the Mirror after returning to her training, Julie said: "Dancing again, surrounded by my friends, is the best feeling in the world."

Darcey Oake

(Image: ITV)

BGT 2014's daredevil illusionist Darcy leaves audiences on the edges of their seats waiting to see if the act goes to plan.

The judges were left completely gobsmacked by his routine in the semi-finals and Darcey will no doubt be pulling out all the stops for his next performance.

Darcey confirmed his act was inspired by his childhood and his dad, wanting to pay homage after his support.

Bars and Melody

Bars and Melody are a pop duo consisting of rapper Leondre 'Bars' Devries and Charlie 'Melody' Lenehan.

They first sang together on BGT way back in 2014. While they finished in third place, their first audition went on to become the most watched ever with more than 200million views.

The duo signed a £500,00 record deal with Simon Cowell's record label Syco and released Hopeful in July 2014.

The pair went onto have huge success in Japan, touring in Osaka, Tokyo and Nagoya.

Brs and Melody then wowed fans of the Champions series with their grown up new look. They performed their own song Here Comes The Sun.

Preacher Lawson

(Image: ITV)

The US funnyman had the British audience in stitches with his stand-up comedy routine and is hoping to tickle funnybones in the final this Saturday.

It's not Preacher's first time competing with such high stakes. After becoming a finalist on America's Got Talent, the 29-year-old went on to finish in fifth place on America's Got Talent: The Champions.

Could it be a case of second time lucky?

Preacher certainly has Ant and Dec's vote after leaving them howling when he licked Ant's face after his first performance.

We'll have to see what he has in store for his next turn.

Britain's Got Talent: The Champions final airs Saturday October 5 at 8.30pm on ITV
description: The ten acts hoping to be crowned winner of the 2019 series revealed - including Stavros Flatley who will perform for the final time
